aws::graph::propositions: # Bell 47G-3B-1 Helicopter Forced Landing Near Vinton, Iowa
The accident occurred on August 6, 2013, around 1030 central daylight time.
A Bell 47G-3B-1 helicopter with registration number N83702 made a forced landing near Vinton, Iowa.
The defining event of the accident was loss of control in flight.
The accident involved collision with terrain/object (non-CFIT).
The commercial pilot was the sole occupant of the helicopter.
The commercial pilot was not injured in the accident.
The helicopter sustained substantial damage.
The helicopter was registered to Benedict Fluke.
The helicopter was operated by Speas Aviation Inc.
The flight operated under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 137.
The flight was an aerial application flight.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed for the flight.
The flight operated without a flight plan.
The flight was local in nature.
The accident occurred during takeoff.
The helicopter was loaded with 60 gallons of spray product.
When the helicopter lifted off the truck bed, the pilot noted that the rotor rpm decreased.
The pilot landed the helicopter after noting the decreased rotor rpm.
The pilot decided to lift off from the ground after the initial landing.
The pilot did not detect any anomalies with the helicopter during the second liftoff.
The pilot flew the helicopter forward at 20 feet above ground level.
The helicopter was traveling at 20-25 miles per hour groundspeed over a bean field.
The rotor rpm decreased again during the flight over the bean field.
The pilot elected to land in the bean field after the second rotor rpm decrease.
The helicopter struck the ground with the tail low.
The tail-low ground strike resulted in damage to the tail rotor and tail boom.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

Takeoff | Loss of control in flight (Defining event)
--- | ---
Takeoff | Collision with terr/obj (non-CFIT)

On August 6, 2013, about 1030 central daylight time, a Bell 47G-3B-1 helicopter, N83702, made a forced landing after experiencing a decrease in engine performance near Vinton, Iowa. The commercial pilot, who was the sole occupant, was not injured. The helicopter sustained substantial damage. The helicopter was registered to Benedict Fluke and operated by Speas Aviation Inc., under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 137 as an aerial application flight. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed for the flight which operated without a flight plan. The local flight was departing at the time of the accident.

In a statement provided by the pilot, the helicopter was loaded with 60 gallons of spray product. When the helicopter lifted off of the truck bed, the pilot noted that the rotor rpm decreased so he landed. The pilot then decided to lift off from the ground and did not detect any anomalies with the helicopter. He flew the helicopter forward at 20 feet AGL and 20-25 miles per hour groundspeed over a bean field. The rotor rpm decreased again so the pilot elected to land in the field. The helicopter struck the ground with the tail low, which resulted in damage to the tail rotor and tail boom.
